elements.content: Two novel series of coordination frameworks [Ln(bta)(H2O)2]·nH2O·mEtOH (Ln = La 1a, n = 4.5, m = 0; Ln = Ce 1b, n = 4, m = 0; Ln = Pr 1c, n = 2.88, m = 0.35) and [Ln2(bta)2(H2O)3]·nH2O (Ln = La 2a, n = 2.14; Ln = Ce 2b, Pr 2c, n = 2) were synthesized by the reaction of 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid (H3bta) with the corresponding lanthanide salts using different methods. X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that all six complexes have 3D channel structures, but in the first series of complexes, each bta3- ligand adopts a cis, trans, trans conformation and acts as a μ5-bridge linking five lanthanide atoms, while in the second series, the bta3- ligands adopt cis, trans, trans and cis, cis, cis conformations and act as μ6- and μ5-bridges, respectively. Thus two series of complexes have the same metal atoms and ligands but different structures. The results show that the flexible triacid ligand is versatile and can adopt different conformations according to different reaction conditions. The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements of complexes 1c and 2c showed that both complexes exhibit antiferromagnetic interactions between the Pr(III) ions.

The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements of complexes 1c and 2c showed that both complexes exhibit antiferromagnetic interactions between the Pr(III) ions.

elements.content: The crystal engineering of coordination frameworks has attracted great interest from chemists, due not only to the unusual topologies and interesting properties but also to their potential applications such as adsorption, ion-exchange, and catalysis. Especially, carboxylate-containing ligands have drawn much attention in recent years owing to the diversity of the binding modes of carboxylate groups to metal atoms. So far, extensive work has been carried out by using carboxylate-containing ligands, for example trimesic acid (TMA), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (p-H2BDC), 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (m-H2BDC), and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid (H4BTEC). The majority of these reports have focused on the complexes with rigid carboxylate-containing ligands; however, the use of flexible ligands as building blocks in the construction of coordination frameworks is attractive because the flexibility and conformational freedoms of the ligands may offer various possibilities for construction of frameworks with unique structures and useful properties. In addition, most of the reported studies so far have focused on coordination frameworks with transition metal salts. However, there has been an upsurge in the use of lanthanide salts for constructing coordination frameworks for their high coordination numbers along with special magnetic and luminescent properties. On the other hand, the studies reported to date suggest that the formation of coordination frameworks is influenced by many factors, such as the nature of ligands, the coordination geometry of metal ions, the ratio between metal salt and ligand, and the reaction conditions. Therefore, further studies on the assembly of metal salts with organic ligands are needed to elucidate and understand the details of the assembly process.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The crystal engineering of coordination frameworks has attracted great interest from chemists, due not only to the unusual topologies and interesting properties but also to their potential applications such as adsorption, ion-exchange, and catalysis. Especially, carboxylate-containing ligands have drawn much attention in recent years owing to the diversity of the binding modes of carboxylate groups to metal atoms. So far, extensive work has been carried out by using carboxylate-containing ligands, for example trimesic acid (TMA), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (p-H2BDC), 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (m-H2BDC), and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid (H4BTEC). The majority of these reports have focused on the complexes with rigid carboxylate-containing ligands; however, the use of flexible ligands as building blocks in the construction of coordination frameworks is attractive because the flexibility and conformational freedoms of the ligands may offer various possibilities for construction of frameworks with unique structures and useful properties. In addition, most of the reported studies so far have focused on coordination frameworks with transition metal salts. However, there has been an upsurge in the use of lanthanide salts for constructing coordination frameworks for their high coordination numbers along with special magnetic and luminescent properties. On the other hand, the studies reported to date suggest that the formation of coordination frameworks is influenced by many factors, such as the nature of ligands, the coordination geometry of metal ions, the ratio between metal salt and ligand, and the reaction conditions. Therefore, further studies on the assembly of metal salts with organic ligands are needed to elucidate and understand the details of the assembly process.

elements.content: We focus our attention on the construction of novel coordination frameworks by using flexible ligands. In this paper, we report novel coordination frameworks [Ln(bta)(H2O)2]·nH2O·mEtOH (Ln = La 1a, n = 4.5, m = 0; Ln = Ce 1b, n = 4, m = 0; Ln = Pr 1c, n = 2.88, m = 0.35) and [Ln2(bta)2(H2O)3]·nH2O (Ln = La 2a, n= 2.14; Ln = Ce 2b, Pr 2c, n = 2) assembled from the flexible tripodal ligand 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid (H3bta) and corresponding lanthanide salts under different conditions, which may provide a useful strategy to construct new coordination frameworks.

elements.content: General Methods. All commercially available chemicals are of reagent grade and were used as received without further purification. Solvents were purified according to the standard methods. C, H, and N analyses were made on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer at the analysis center of Nanjing University. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer by using KBr disks. Thermogravimetric and differential thermal analyses were performed on a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer. Powder samples were loaded into alumina pans and heated under N2 at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were taken on a Rigaku D/max-RA rotating anode X-ray diffractometer with graphite-monochromatic Cu Kα (λ = 1.542 Å) radiation at room temperature. The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities in the temperature range of 1.8−300 K under a constant external magnetic field of 2.0 k Gs were performed in an MPMS-SQUID magnetometer. The diamagnetic contributions of the samples were corrected by using Pascal's constants.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 General Methods. All commercially available chemicals are of reagent grade and were used as received without further purification. Solvents were purified according to the standard methods. C, H, and N analyses were made on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer at the analysis center of Nanjing University. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer by using KBr disks. Thermogravimetric and differential thermal analyses were performed on a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer. Powder samples were loaded into alumina pans and heated under N2 at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were taken on a Rigaku D/max-RA rotating anode X-ray diffractometer with graphite-monochromatic Cu Kα (λ = 1.542 Å) radiation at room temperature. The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities in the temperature range of 1.8-300 K under a constant external magnetic field of 2.0 k Gs were performed in an MPMS-SQUID magnetometer. The diamagnetic contributions of the samples were corrected by using Pascal's constants.

elements.content: Preparation of the Complexes. The compound H3bta was prepared according to the method described in the literature. Hydrated lanthanide salts were prepared from the corresponding oxides according to literature methods. The nonintegral numbers of the uncoordinated solvents (H2O and EtOH) in compounds 1c and 2a were achieved by X-ray single diffraction analyses and confirmed by thermogravimetric and elemental analyses.

elements.content: (a) [La(bta)(H 2 O) 2 ]·4.5H 2 O (1a). The aqueous solution of the tetraethylammonium salt of 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid was readily prepared by the reaction of tetraethylammonium hydroxide with H3bta in water until pH = 7. The title compound 1a was prepared by slow diffusion between two layers of an aqueous solution (10 mL) of the tetraethylammonium salt of H3bta (0.0252 g, 0.1 mmol) and LaCl3·6H2O (0.0355 g, 0.1 mmol) in ethanol (10 mL) at room temperature. About 1 week later, colorless platelet crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained in 76% yield. Anal. Calcd for compound 1a, C12H21O12La {[La(bta)(H2O)2]·4H2O partial lattice water molecule lost at room temperature}:  C, 29.05; H, 4.27. Found:  C, 29.14; H, 4.59. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3446 br, 1637 m, 1545 vs, 1425 s, 1415 s, 1394 vs, 1272 s, 1172 w, 1046 w, 742 m, 624 m.

elements.content: (c) [La 2 (bta) 2 (H 2 O) 3 ]·2.14H 2 O (2a). The complex was prepared by solvothermal reaction. A mixture of 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid (0.0252 g, 0.1 mmol), LaCl3·6H2O (0.0353 g, 0.1 mmol), MnCO3 (0.0172 g, 0.15 mmol), C2H5OH (2 mL), and H2O (12 mL) was sealed into a bomb equipped with a Teflon liner and then heated at 170 °C for 3 days. After slow cooling of the reaction mixture to room temperature, colorless block crystals for compound 2a were obtained in ca. 72% yield (based on ligand) as a single phase. Anal. Calcd for compound 2a, C24H28.28O17.14La2:  C, 33.17; H, 3.28. Found:  C, 32.51; H, 3.45. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3566 m, 3385 br, 1605 s, 1543 vs, 1443 s, 1413 vs, 1305 w, 1269 w, 1173 w, 814 w, 739 w, 699 m.

elements.content: Crystallography. The collection of crystallographic data for the complexes 1a−c and 2a−c was carried out on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID Imaging Plate diffractometer at 200 K, using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.7107 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods with SIR92 and expanded using the Fourier technique. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the full-matrix least-squares method. The hydrogen atoms except for those of water molecules were generated geometrically. All calculations were carried out on an SGI workstation using the teXsan crystallographic software package of Molecular Structure Corp. Details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinement are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles of complexes 1a and 2c with their estimated standard deviations are listed in Table ; other complexes are listed in Table S1 in the Supporting Information.

Syntheses. It has been demonstrated that complete deprotonation of the triacid is essential in order to bind metal ions in a multidentate fashion and to increase the dimensionality of the coordination frameworks. Thus we employed tetraethylammonium hydroxide or tetra-tert-butylammonium hydroxide (t-Bu4NOH) to neutralize the 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid in the study of the first series of complexes. As expected, three coordination frameworks 1a−c were obtained in satisfying yields. In addition, to investigate coordination frameworks containing lanthanide metal atoms together with transition-metal atoms, we began to assemble H3bta, lanthanide salts, and transition-metal salts into polymeric complexes under hydrothermal conditions. The reaction of 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid, LaCl3·6H2O, and MnCO3 resulted in the formation of crystalline 2a with good yield. But unexpectedly, it did not form a heterometallic framework. Then we changed many factors, such as the lanthanide salts, the transition-metal salts, and the hydrothermal conditions including temperature, reaction time, and solvents; unfortunately only the complexes 2b and 2c were isolated. The reactions of 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid with LaCl3·6H2O by addition of carbonate salts of alkaline or alkaline-earth metals were also tried, but no satisfied complexes were obtained.

Results and Discussion

 Syntheses. It has been demonstrated that complete deprotonation of the triacid is essential in order to bind metal ions in a multidentate fashion and to increase the dimensionality of the coordination frameworks. Thus we employed tetraethylammonium hydroxide or tetra-tert-butylammonium hydroxide (t-Bu4NOH) to neutralize the 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid in the study of the first series of complexes. As expected, three coordination frameworks 1a-c were obtained in satisfying yields. In  addition, to investigate coordination frameworks containing lanthanide metal atoms together with transition-metal atoms, we began to assemble H3bta, lanthanide salts, and transition-metal salts into polymeric complexes under hydrothermal conditions. The reaction of 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid, LaCl3⋅6H2O, and MnCO3 resulted in the formation of crystalline 2a with good yield. But unexpectedly, it did not form a heterometallic framework. Then we changed many factors, such as the lanthanide salts, the transition-metal salts, and the hydrothermal conditions including temperature, reaction time, and solvents; unfortunately only the complexes 2b and 2c were isolated. The reactions of 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid with LaCl3⋅6H2O by addition of carbonate salts of alkaline or alkaline-earth metals were also tried, but no satisfied complexes were obtained.

elements.content: Crystal Structure of 1a − c. The same space group and similar cell parameters as listed in Table indicate that complexes 1a, 1b, and 1c are isomorphous and isostructural. As a typical example, the structure of complex 1a is described here in detail. The La(III) center is coordinated by nine oxygen atoms, in which seven are from five bta3- ligands and two from coordinated water molecules (Figure ). The La−O distances range from 2.398(3) to 2.678(3) Å, similar to other related La−O distances, and the O−La−O coordination angles vary from 49.25(8)° to 158.02(9)° (Table ). In this complex, all carboxyl groups of 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acids are deprotonated, in good agreement with the IR spectral data since no strong bands around 1702 cm-1 for −COOH were observed. Each bta3- ligand acts as a μ5-bridge linking five lanthanum atoms (Figure ), in which one carboxylate group adopts a monodentate mode coordinating to one lanthanum atom, while each of the other two carboxylate groups adopts a μ2-η2:η1-bridging (namely one oxygen atom of the carboxylate connects two metal ions, the other one connects one metal ion and the carboxylate group coordinates to two metal ions) coordination mode connecting two lanthanum atoms. If we neglect the linking functions of the monodentate carboxylate groups in bta3-, a two-dimensional network with the nearest metal−metal distance of 4.30 Å (e.g. the distances of La1−La1A, La1A-La1D, and La1D-La1E) is obtained (Figure ). In this network the La(III) atoms and μ2-η2:η1-bridging oxygen atoms form an infinite 1D La−O chain, and in each chain the La(III) atoms are almost in a straight line (the angles of ∠La1−La1A-La1D and ∠La1−La1D-La1E are 176 and 178°, respectively); then the bridged bta3- ligands adopt a cis, trans, trans conformation and link these 1D chains to generate a ladderlike 2D network (Figure ). The 2D networks are further linked together by the monodentate carboxylate groups to produce a new 3D porous coordination framework with channel dimensions of ca. 10.76 × 8.62 Å (Figure ), and the uncoordinated water molecules are trapped in the channels (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: Crystal Structure of 2a − c. The X-ray crystallographic study revealed that complexes 2a, 2b, and 2c are isomorphous and isostructural (Table ), so complex 2c represents this series for detailed structural description. As shown in Figure , the asymmetric unit of 2c contains two kinds of Pr(III) atoms with different coordination environments. The Pr1 ion is coordinated by nine oxygen atoms, eight from six bta3- ligands and one from a water molecule, while the Pr2 ion is surrounded by nine oxygen atoms in which seven are from five bta3- anions and two from water molecules. The Pr−O distances range from 2.430 to 2.798 Å, and the average distance of Pr−O is 2.52 Å. The nearest distance between Pr1 and Pr2 is 4.22 Å, indicating the lack of direct metal−metal interaction. In this complex, 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acids are also completely deprotonated. It is interesting that there are two kinds of bta3- anions with different conformation and binding modes. One, named abta3-, is adopting a cis, cis, cis conformation and acting as a μ5-bridge to link five praseodymium atoms (Figure a), in which one carboxylate group adopts a μ1-η1:η1-chelating (each oxygen atom of the carboxylate connects one metal ion and the carboxylate group coordinates to one metal ion) mode coordinating to one praseodymium atom, while each of the other two carboxylate groups adopts a μ2-η2:η1-bridging coordination mode connecting two praseodymium atoms. The other one, named bbta3-, is adopting a cis, trans, trans conformation and acting as a μ6-bridge linking six praseodymium atoms (Figure b), in which one carboxylate group adopts a μ2-η2:η1-bridging coordination mode, while each of the other two carboxylate groups adopts a μ2-η1:η1-bridging (one oxygen atom coordinates to one metal ion, and one carboxylate group coordinates to two metal ions) coordination mode. These two kinds of bta3- anions play different roles in the formation of the coordination framework. Every two abta3- ligands adopt face-to-face orientation and connect eight metal atoms to give a 1D tubelike chain (Figure ), and the section of the tube is a 20-membered macrocyclic ring formed by two Pr(III) atoms and two abta3- ligands (each abta3- using two of the three pendant arms connects two Pr atoms). Then the 1D tubes linked by the μ2-η1:η1-bridging carboxylate groups from bbta3- ligands to form a 2D layered structure (Figure S3). The 2D layers are further joined together by the μ2-η2:η1-bridging carboxylate groups from bbta3- ligands, producing a 3D structure with channels along the b axis (Figure ).

elements.content: Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) of Complexes. The thermogravimetric analyses were carried out in the range of 20−800 °C under nitrogen atmosphere. The TGA data for 1a show that the initial weight loss occurred from 30 to 220 °C corresponding to the loss of the noncoordinated and coordinated water molecules; the second weight loss begins at 395 °C where the decomposition of the residue starts. Unfortunately, the X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns showed that the framework of the complexes collapsed after removing the water molecules since the most characteristic XRD peaks disappeared. A distinction between the loss of the coordinated and uncoordinated water molecules was not clearly observed from the TGA data. This nondistinctive behavior is also reported in the literature.

elements.content: The TGA data of 2c show that the first weight loss of 10.6% (calcd, 10.3%) from 65 to 185 °C corresponds to the loss of all water molecules (including two uncoordinated water and three coordinated water molecules). A distinction between the two kinds of water molecules was also not clear, and no further weight loss was observed over the temperature range of 185−410 °C.

elements.content: Magnetic Properties of Complexes 1c and 2c. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on powder samples of 1c and 2c in the temperature range of 1.8−300 K. Figure gives plots of χ M T vs T and χ M vs T for complex 1c. The χ M value is 0.00454 emu mol-1 at 300 K. With the decrease of the temperature, the values of χ M increase over the region of 4−300 K. There is a smooth increase, and a maximum is reached at 4 K (χ M = 0.0267 emu mol-1). From 4 K there is a clear decrease of the χ M (Figure , insert). The χ M T value at room temperature is 1.36 emu K mol-1, which is lower than the spin-only value of 1.6 emu K mol-1 for the Pr(III) unit (3H4, g = 0.8, S = 1), and χ M T decreases gradually by cooling the sample and reaches 0.0452 emu K mol-1 at 1.8 K. The shape of these curves is a characteristic occurrence of antiferromagnetic interactions between the Pr(III) centers. According to the structural characteristics, complex 1c may exhibit Pr(III)−Pr(III) magnetic interactions mediated by carboxylate groups. Figure a shows the structure of the Pr(III)−O−Pr(III) chain which may mediate the magnetic exchange.

With the decrease of the temperature, the values of χ M increase over the region of 4-300 K. There is a smooth increase, and a maximum is reached at 4 K (χ M = 0.0267 emu mol-1). From 4 K there is a clear decrease of the χ M (Figure , insert). The χ M T value at room temperature is 1.36 emu K mol-1, which is lower than the spin-only value of 1.6 emu K mol-1 for the Pr(III) unit (3H4, g = 0.8, S = 1), and χ M T decreases gradually by cooling the sample and reaches 0.0452 emu K mol-1 at 1.8 K. The shape of these curves is a characteristic occurrence of antiferromagnetic interactions between the Pr(III) centers. According to the structural characteristics, complex 1c may exhibit Pr(III)-Pr(III) magnetic interactions mediated by carboxylate groups. Figure a shows the structure of the Pr(III)-O-Pr(III) chain which may mediate the magnetic exchange.

elements.content: The plot of the temperature dependence of magnetic properties for complex 2c is very similar to that of complex 1c (see Figure S3). The χ M value is 0.00941 emu mol-1 at 300 K, and the maximum is reached at 3 K (χ M = 0.0796 emu mol-1). At room temperature, χ M T is 2.83 emu K mol-1, which is lower than the value (3.2 emu K mol-1) for two isolated Pr(III) ions according to the asymmetrical unit of the structure (g = 0.8, S = 1), and χ M T gradually decreases when the temperature is lowered and reaches 0.14 emu K mol-1 at 1.8 K. The data also suggest the antiferromagnetic interactions between the Pr(III) ions. The possible Pr(III)−Pr(III) magnetic exchange chain in complex 2c is shown in Figure b.

elements.content: We have successfully assembled 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid (H3bta) and Ln(III) (Ln = La, Ce, Pr) salts into two novel series of 3D channel-like coordination frameworks, [Ln(bta)(H2O)2]·nH2O·mEtOH (Ln = La 1a, n = 4.5, m = 0; Ln = Ce 1b, n = 4, m = 0; Ln = Pr 1c, n = 2.88, m = 0.35) and [Ln2(bta)2(H2O)3]·nH2O (Ln = La 2a, n = 2.14; Ln = Ce 2b, Pr 2c, n = 2). The results show that the synthetic methods play a crucial role in determining the structure of the complexes, especially for the second series, and the addition of transition metals influenced the final structures of the complexes. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements on complexes 1c and 2c indicate antiferromagnetic interactions between the Pr(III) ions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have successfully assembled 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid (H3bta) and Ln(III) (Ln = La, Ce, Pr) salts into two novel series of 3D channel-like coordination frameworks, [Ln(bta)(H2O)2]⋅nH2O⋅mEtOH (Ln = La 1a, n = 4.5, m = 0; Ln = Ce 1b, n = 4, m = 0; Ln = Pr 1c, n = 2.88, m = 0.35) and [Ln2(bta)2(H2O)3]⋅nH2O (Ln = La 2a, n = 2.14; Ln = Ce 2b, Pr 2c, n = 2). The results show that the synthetic methods play a crucial role in determining the structure of the complexes, especially for the second series, and the addition of transition metals influenced the final structures of the complexes. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements on complexes 1c and 2c indicate antiferromagnetic interactions between the Pr(III) ions.

(a) [La(bta)(H 2 O) 2 ]·4.5H 2 O (1a). The aqueous solution of the tetraethylammonium salt of 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid was readily prepared by the reaction of tetraethylammonium hydroxide with H3bta in water until pH = 7. The title compound 1a was prepared by slow diffusion between two layers of an aqueous solution (10 mL) of the tetraethylammonium salt of H3bta (0.0252 g, 0.1 mmol) and LaCl3·6H2O (0.0355 g, 0.1 mmol) in ethanol (10 mL) at room temperature. About 1 week later, colorless platelet crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained in 76% yield. Anal. Calcd for compound 1a, C12H21O12La {[La(bta)(H2O)2]·4H2O partial lattice water molecule lost at room temperature}:  C, 29.05; H, 4.27. Found:  C, 29.14; H, 4.59. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3446 br, 1637 m, 1545 vs, 1425 s, 1415 s, 1394 vs, 1272 s, 1172 w, 1046 w, 742 m, 624 m.

(b) [Ce(bta)(H 2 O) 2 ]·4H 2 O (1b) and [Pr(bta)(H 2 O) 2 ]·2.88H 2 O·0.35EtOH (1c). These two complexes were obtained similarly to compound 1a from LnCl3·6H2O (Ln = Ce, Pr) instead of LaCl3·6H2O and tetra-tert-butylammonium hydroxide instead of tetraethylammonium hydroxide. Yield:  1b, 72%; 1c, 74%. Anal. Calcd for compound 1b, C12H21O12Ce:  C, 28.98; H, 4.26. Found:  C, 29.06; H, 4.31. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3424 br, 1638 m, 1545 vs, 1425 s, 1416 s, 1395 vs, 1273 s, 1172 w, 1046 w, 741 m, 624 m. Anal. Calcd for 1c, C12.69H22.35O11.98Pr:  C, 30.03; H, 4.44. Found:  C, 30.15; H, 4.37. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3423 br, 1638 s, 1546 vs, 1427 s, 1416 s, 1395 vs, 1273 s, 1172 w, 1046 w, 742 m, 625 m.

(c) [La 2 (bta) 2 (H 2 O) 3 ]·2.14H 2 O (2a). The complex was prepared by solvothermal reaction. A mixture of 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid (0.0252 g, 0.1 mmol), LaCl3·6H2O (0.0353 g, 0.1 mmol), MnCO3 (0.0172 g, 0.15 mmol), C2H5OH (2 mL), and H2O (12 mL) was sealed into a bomb equipped with a Teflon liner and then heated at 170 °C for 3 days. After slow cooling of the reaction mixture to room temperature, colorless block crystals for compound 2a were obtained in ca. 72% yield (based on ligand) as a single phase. Anal. Calcd for compound 2a, C24H28.28O17.14La2:  C, 33.17; H, 3.28. Found:  C, 32.51; H, 3.45. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3566 m, 3385 br, 1605 s, 1543 vs, 1443 s, 1413 vs, 1305 w, 1269 w, 1173 w, 814 w, 739 w, 699 m.

(d) [Ce 2 (bta) 2 (H 2 O) 3 ]·2H 2 O (2b). The complex was prepared in a manner similar to that of 2a. A mixture of 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid (0.0504 g, 0.2 mmol), CeCl3·6H2O (0.0354 g, 0.1 mmol), MnCO3 (0.0172 g, 0.15 mmol), acetic acid (0.5 mL), and H2O (12 mL) was sealed into a bomb equipped with a Teflon liner and then heated at 145 °C for 4 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, yellow block crystals were obtained in 60% yield. Anal. Calcd for compound 2b, C24H28O17Ce2:  C, 33.18; H, 3.25. Found:  C, 33.14; H, 2.92. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3567 m, 3417 br, 1605 s, 1542 vs, 1444 s, 1416 vs, 1305 w, 1270 m, 1173 w, 814 w, 738 w, 699 m.

(e) [Pr 2 (bta) 2 (H 2 O) 3 ]·2H 2 O (2c). The complex was prepared in a manner similar to that of 2b. A mixture of 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid (0.0504 g, 0.2 mmol), Pr(NO3)3·6H2O (0.0435 g, 0.1 mmol), MnCO3 (0.0172 g, 0.15 mmol) or CdCO3 (0.0259 g, 0.15 mmol), acetic acid (0.5 mL), and H2O (12 mL) was sealed into a bomb equipped with a Teflon liner and then heated at 140 °C for 105 h. After slow cooling to room temperature, yellow block crystals were obtained in 53% yield. Anal. Calcd for compound 2c, C24H28O17Pr2:  C, 33.12; H, 3.24. Found:  C, 33.08; H, 3.17. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3567 m, 3385 br, 1605 s, 1543 vs, 1444 s, 1418 vs, 1314 m, 1270 m, 1173 m, 814 w, 738 w, 701 m.

cln_elements.content:
Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) of Complexes. The thermogravimetric analyses were carried out in the range of 20−800 °C under nitrogen atmosphere. The TGA data for 1a show that the initial weight loss occurred from 30 to 220 °C corresponding to the loss of the noncoordinated and coordinated water molecules; the second weight loss begins at 395 °C where the decomposition of the residue starts. Unfortunately, the X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns showed that the framework of the complexes collapsed after removing the water molecules since the most characteristic XRD peaks disappeared. A distinction between the loss of the coordinated and uncoordinated water molecules was not clearly observed from the TGA data. This nondistinctive behavior is also reported in the literature.

The TGA data of 2c show that the first weight loss of 10.6% (calcd, 10.3%) from 65 to 185 °C corresponds to the loss of all water molecules (including two uncoordinated water and three coordinated water molecules). A distinction between the two kinds of water molecules was also not clear, and no further weight loss was observed over the temperature range of 185−410 °C.

Magnetic Properties of Complexes 1c and 2c. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on powder samples of 1c and 2c in the temperature range of 1.8−300 K. Figure gives plots of χ M T vs T and χ M vs T for complex 1c. The χ M value is 0.00454 emu mol-1 at 300 K. With the decrease of the temperature, the values of χ M increase over the region of 4−300 K. There is a smooth increase, and a maximum is reached at 4 K (χ M = 0.0267 emu mol-1). From 4 K there is a clear decrease of the χ M (Figure , insert). The χ M T value at room temperature is 1.36 emu K mol-1, which is lower than the spin-only value of 1.6 emu K mol-1 for the Pr(III) unit (3H4, g = 0.8, S = 1), and χ M T decreases gradually by cooling the sample and reaches 0.0452 emu K mol-1 at 1.8 K. The shape of these curves is a characteristic occurrence of antiferromagnetic interactions between the Pr(III) centers. According to the structural characteristics, complex 1c may exhibit Pr(III)−Pr(III) magnetic interactions mediated by carboxylate groups. Figure a shows the structure of the Pr(III)−O−Pr(III) chain which may mediate the magnetic exchange.

The plot of the temperature dependence of magnetic properties for complex 2c is very similar to that of complex 1c (see Figure S3). The χ M value is 0.00941 emu mol-1 at 300 K, and the maximum is reached at 3 K (χ M = 0.0796 emu mol-1). At room temperature, χ M T is 2.83 emu K mol-1, which is lower than the value (3.2 emu K mol-1) for two isolated Pr(III) ions according to the asymmetrical unit of the structure (g = 0.8, S = 1), and χ M T gradually decreases when the temperature is lowered and reaches 0.14 emu K mol-1 at 1.8 K. The data also suggest the antiferromagnetic interactions between the Pr(III) ions. The possible Pr(III)−Pr(III) magnetic exchange chain in complex 2c is shown in Figure b.
